audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Engineer, Trainer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer

creditText: French, Andrew; Pridmore, Tony; Mellor, Nathan
description: This six-week course from the University of Nottingham will introduce you to the fundamentals of image analysis and its applications in plant phenotyping. You’ll learn how to use imaging technologies to collect data from images and perform detailed analyses. By the end of the course, you’ll be able to extract meaningful information from image data without any destruction or harm to the subjects of your study.

headline: RNA-req Data readiness for machine learning applications
audience: Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Clinician, Engineer, Trainer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Open Research Specialist, Research skills educator
author: Edward Parkinson, Munazah Andrabi, Katarzyna Kamieniecka
creditText: Edward Parkinson, Munazah Andrabi, Katarzyna Kamieniecka
description:
This lesson provides a practical guide to sourcing and pre-processing a bulk RNA-Seq dataset for use in a machine learning classification task. The lessons explains the characteristics of a dataset required for this type of analysis, how to search for and download a dataset from each of the main public functional genomics repositories, and then provides guidelines on how to pre-process a dataset to make it machine learning ready, with detailed examples. The lesson finally explains some of the additional data filtering and transformation steps that will improve the performance of machine learning algorithms using RNA-Seq count data.
The lesson is written in the context of a supervised machine learning classification modelling task, where the goal is to construct a model that is able to differentiate two different disease states (e.g. disease vs. healthy control) based on the gene expression profile.
funding: ELIXIR-UK: FAIR data stewardship training. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038966/1).

headline: FAIR data management for Long-term agriculture experiments
audience: Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Trainer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Open Research Specialist, Research skills educator, Undergraduate student
author: Richard Ostler
creditText: Richard Ostler
description: This lesson is aimed at long-term agricultural experiment (LTE) managers, and researchers interested in using long-term agricultural experiment data, who want to apply FAIR principles and good research data management practices to their LTE data. While the target audience for this lesson is therefore LTE managers and researchers, the lesson covers many data management and FAIR data topics relevant to a broader audience working on agricultural field trials.
funding: ELIXIR-UK: FAIR data stewardship training. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038966/1).

headline: FAIR pointers
author: Robert Andrews, Nick Juty, Munazah Andrabi, Nicola Soranzo, Sara Morsy, Kellie Snow, Korneel Hens, Philippe Rocca-Serra, Laura Cooper, Xenia Perez Sitja, Andrew Mason, Branka Franicevic, Saskia Lawson-Tovey, Krzysztof Poterlowicz, Katarzyna Kamieniecka
creditText: Robert Andrews, Nick Juty, Munazah Andrabi, Nicola Soranzo, Sara Morsy, Kellie Snow, Korneel Hens, Philippe Rocca-Serra, Laura Cooper, Xenia Perez Sitja, Andrew Mason, Branka Franicevic, Saskia Lawson-Tovey, Krzysztof Poterlowicz, Katarzyna Kamieniecka
description: This short Carpentries-style course caters for people working in the Life Sciences with little or no experience with the FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable). The course aims to concisely introduce FAIR, its concepts and terminology and supplement all material with signposting to helpful FAIR resources. These resources include RDMkit, FAIR Cookbook, RDMbites, FAIRsharing and the Data Stewardship Wizard, offered through the ELIXIR open-access infrastructure, supporting FAIR research data management.
funding: ELIXIR-UK: FAIR data stewardship training. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038966/1).

headline: Workflows with Nextflow
audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Researcher, Clinician, Industry, Bioinformatican, Open Research Specialist, Public sector

creditText: Grimes, G. R., Floden, E., Di Tommaso, P., Ewels, P., & Garcia, M. (2021). Introduction to Workflows with Nextflow and nf-core. https://github.com/carpentries-incubator/workflows-nextflow
description: Introduction to bioinformatics workflows with Nextflow and nf-core. Nextflow is a workflow management system for building and sharing computational pipelines that facilitate reproducible data science workflows. nf-core is a community-led repository of high quality bioinformatics workflows using Nextflow.
funding: Ed-DASH Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V039075/1).

headline: Python Fundamentals
audience: Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Clinician, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator, Postgraduate taught student
author: Learn to Discover (L2D)
competencyRequired: Computing: Understanding of hierarchical filesystems including root and home directories, Computing: Understanding of File types and formats including plain text files and the relation between file types and file extensions
copyrightNotice: © Learn to Discover (L2D). All rights reserved.
description: A comprehensive introduction to programming in Python for learners with limited or no prior experience. The module covers core programming concepts, algorithmic thinking, input/output, variables and data types, logical operations, conditionals, iterations, functions, basic data structures, and working with arrays, lists, tuples and strings. It prepares learners for data-focused work and is a prerequisite for subsequent L2D modules in Data Handling and Machine Learning.
educationalAlignment: Introductory Python programming for data science in biosciences and medicine
funding: Learn to Discover (L2D). Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars

headline: Data Handling
audience: Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Clinician, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator, Postgraduate taught student

copyrightNotice: © Learn to Discover (L2D). All rights reserved.
description: A hands-on introduction to data handling in Python, building directly on the Python Fundamentals module. Learners work with NumPy arrays and pandas DataFrames to import, clean, manipulate, analyse and visualise numerical, tabular and image data. Topics include univariate and multivariate analysis, basic statistics, plotting with Matplotlib, and good practice in data workflows. Successful completion is a compulsory prerequisite for the Machine Learning module.
educationalAlignment: Introductory data handling and visualisation for data science in biosciences and medicine
funding: Learn to Discover (L2D). Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars
teaches: Classical statistics: Understanding independent/expanatory variables and dependent/response variables, "Classical statistics: Understanding variable types such as discrete, nominal, ordinal, continuous", Classical statistics: Understanding that variables have distributions, Python Programming: Ability to work with Python libraries for scientific computing such as NumPy and pandas, Python Programming: Ability to use NumPy arrays for numerical computing, Python Programming: Ability to create and manipulate pandas DataFrames, Python Programming: Ability to import tabular data from CSV and Excel files into pandas, Python Programming: Ability to clean data including handling missing values and inconsistent entries, "Python Programming: Ability to filter, sort and subset tabular data using pandas", Python Programming: Ability to group and aggregate data in pandas, Python Programming: Ability to merge and join multiple DataFrames, "Python Programming: Ability to calculate descriptive statistics such as mean, median, variance and quantiles in Python", "Python Programming: Ability to create basic data visualisations including histograms, boxplots, scatter plots and line plots", Python Programming: Ability to use Matplotlib or similar libraries for publication-quality plots, Data management: Ability to document and share data analysis workflows, Data management: Understanding of data integrity and quality control in bioinformatics, Data management: Ability to use version control systems for data analysis projects

description: A practical introduction to network science for data-rich bioscience and medical applications. Learners explore graphs and network representations of complex systems, network measures and quantification, and network visualisation. The module focuses on applying network analysis techniques to real-world case studies, with an emphasis on interpreting results in a research context.
educationalAlignment: Introductory network science for data science in biosciences and medicine
funding: Learn to Discover (L2D). Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars
teaches: Network Science: Understanding of graphs as representations of complex systems, "Network Science: Understanding of nodes, edges, degree and paths in networks", Network Science: Ability to construct network representations from tabular data, "Network Science: Ability to calculate basic network measures such as degree distribution, centrality and clustering coefficient", Network Science: Ability to visualise networks using appropriate layouts, Network Science: Ability to interpret network measures in the context of bioscience or medical case studies

description: An applied machine learning module building on Python programming and data handling skills. Learners implement supervised and unsupervised machine learning methods using scikit-learn, including classification algorithms, clustering and dimensionality reduction. The module covers model evaluation, performance improvement and robustness, and emphasises understanding why models work and what they reveal about data.
educationalAlignment: Applied machine learning for data science in biosciences and medicine
funding: Learn to Discover (L2D). Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars

copyrightNotice: © Learn to Discover (L2D). All rights reserved.
description: An advanced module that builds on the Machine Learning component of the L2D curriculum. The module introduces core concepts in artificial intelligence, focusing on three primary AI paradigms (for example, logical/symbolic approaches, probabilistic methods and modern neural approaches). Learners examine how AI systems are constructed, their applications in research, and the broader implications of AI in bioscience and medicine.
educationalAlignment: Advanced artificial intelligence concepts and applications for research
funding: Learn to Discover (L2D). Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars
teaches: "Artificial Intelligence: Understanding of symbolic, probabilistic and neural approaches to AI", "Artificial Intelligence: Understanding of how AI systems are constructed from data, models and objectives", Artificial Intelligence: Ability to compare strengths and limitations of different AI paradigms for research problems, "Artificial Intelligence: Awareness of ethical, legal and social implications of AI in bioscience and medicine", Artificial Intelligence: Understanding of the relationship between classical machine learning and modern AI systems

headline: Introduction to Plant Phenotyping Technologies
audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Research skills educator, Trainer
author: Atkinson, Jonathan; Postnikov, Andrey; Gaju, Oorbessy
creditText: Atkinson, Jonathan; Postnikov, Andrey; Gaju, Oorbessy
description: On this four-week course, you’ll delve into some of the various technologies used in plant phenotyping, learning about data generation in different environments – both the advantages and challenges. By the end of the course, you‘ll be able to demonstrate understanding of plant phenotyping concepts on several levels: from basic principles to modern state, challenges, and different robot kits for data collection.
funding: Data CAMPP. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038850/1).
teaches: Bioscience: Plant phenotyping

audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Trainer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator
author: French, Andrew; Parsons, Simon
creditText: French, Andrew; Parsons, Simon
description: On this five-week course from the University of Nottingham, you’ll gain an overview of the applications of machine learning for image data, focusing specifically on its use in plant phenotyping.
funding: Data CAMPP. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038850/1).
keywords: machine learning, image analysis, plant phenotyping
teaches: Machine Learning: Understanding machine learning techniques for bioscience image data, Image processing: Understanding of basics of image analysis

headline: Experimental Design for Machine Learning
audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Trainer, Engineer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator
author: Pound, Michael; French, Andrew; Mellor, Nathan
creditText: Pound, Michael; French, Andrew; Mellor, Nathan
description: This course is designed to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application, providing a comprehensive understanding of how experimental design principles can optimise machine learning outcomes. By the end of this course, you’ll have a deep understanding of how experimental design supports machine learning, driving innovation in biosciences.
funding: Data CAMPP. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038850/1).
keywords: machine learning, plant phenotyping, experimental design
teaches: Experimental Design: Understanding foundations of experimental design for machine learning , Machine Learning: Understanding ML methodologies

headline: Deep Learning for Bioscientists
audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Trainer, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator
author: Pound, Michael; Mellor, Nathan
creditText: Pound, Michael; Mellor, Nathan
description: On this five-week course, you’ll develop essential knowledge of deep learning to understand how it can help your research in bioscience. You’ll be guided through deep learning techniques and gain practical skills you can use outside of the course. Throughout the course, you’ll take part in practical exercises to cement your knowledge and ensure you can use your skills in your context.
funding: Data CAMPP. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038850/1).
teaches: Machine Learning: Understanding deep learning, Machine Learning: Use of PyTorch for deep learning

headline: Generative AI for Plant Phenotyping
audience: Undergraduate student, Postgraduate taught student, Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Trainer, Industry, Public sector, Research Software Engineer, Bioinformatican, Research skills educator
author: Pound, Michael; French, Andrew; Mellor, Nathan
creditText: Pound, Michael; French, Andrew; Mellor, Nathan
description: On this five-week online course with the University of Nottingham, you’ll dive into the essentials of generative AI, including large language models (LLMs) and image generation methods. You’ll learn how to harness AI to address challenges like missing data and generate insightful visualisations to enhance your research. Through practical examples, you’ll explore how AI can be integrated into bioscience workflows, empowering you to make significant advancements in your field.
funding: Data CAMPP. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038850/1).
keywords: generative AI, machine learning, plant phenotyping
teaches: Artificial Intelligence: Understanding generative AI methods

headline: Artificial Intelligence in Health Analytics
audience: Postgraduate research student, Researcher, Clinician, Industry
author: Cummins, Nicholas; Dinely, Judith; Stahl, Daniel; Abdullah, Zahra; Langham, John;
creditText: Cummins, Nicholas; Dinely, Judith; Stahl, Daniel; Abdullah, Zahra; Langham, John;
description:
This course introduces you to the fundamental techniques and concepts necessary for understanding and implementing AI applications in healthcare. AI concepts covered include; an introduction to intelligent agents; problem-solving strategies such as evolutionary algorithms and particle swarm optimisation; constraint satisfaction problems; modelling uncertainty; and, learning methods including deep learning and reinforcement learning.

Throughout this course, you will gain valuable hands-on experience by implementing AI techniques, using real healthcare data examples, in Python as well as learning to assess and validate the resulting models.
funding: Innovation Scholars Big Data Skills Training. Funded by UKRI Innovation Scholars (MR/V038664/1).
keywords: programming, data processing, deep learning, python
teaches: Artificial Intelligence: , Machine Learning: Understanding deep learning
